utterances: Hi.

This is DAY TO DAY from NPR News.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
Iran has a new president.
Religious conservative Mahmoud Ahmadinejad today took over from former pro-reform cleric Mohammad Khatami.
The change comes as Iran faces important questions over the future of its nuclear program and the direction of its internal policies.
The presidential elections last June brought Ahmadinejad to power, causing some to fear a return of a fundamentalist regime.
With us now is one young Iranian who voted in that election.
Amir Aram(ph) is a college student and English translator, and he joins us from Tehran.
And, Mr. Aram, welcome to the program.
Thanks.
My pleasure.
So what do you think of your new president?
Well, actually, there are different points of views about the new president.
Most, you know, important problem of Iranians that has been considered by many is the financial problems, economical problems and also the unemployment.
If you want to talk about the new president, I should say that he had some words, you know, stressing on solving such problems.
If he comes to bring his words into action, I think it would be great.
But if not, you know, we have to regret that, once more, Iranian people went to go and vote for someone who didn't bring his words into action.
Did you vote for him?
